ratings.comment: While Bernstein is a good person and definitely means well and wants her students to succeed, she turned a class that had amazing potential into one that I dreaded going to and doing work for. Her instructions are often unclear, she pushes her opinions onto students unintentionally, and she assigns more work than necessary. Not the best approach.

Enthusiastic, sweet, and interested in what her students have to say in their essays, but occasionally frustrating and not always open to different ideas. Assigned readings are interesting and reasonable, if a little heavy at times. Expectations aren't always clear but she is very willing to help.

Just like most other english teachers I've had; slightly out of touch with her students and modern academics in general, belligerently confident in her opinions and regarded everyone else's as unimportant, comments on my papers were very debatable and often contradicted each other. Can't go 5 minutes without reminding us she writes books.

Bernstein may be a good person, but she is not a good teacher.  She is egocentric and has only one way of approaching literature. Her expecations for reading are too high, and she seems to enjoy putting down people's ideas in class. I ended up writing papers just to please her and give her what she wanted to hear. Bad communicator.

Very enthusiastic about literature, seems to really love teaching. Her course  stretched me as a writer, took my essay writing to a new level, although the rewriting process was often very stressful. She has high expectations for student writing. Downsides: Could be better at fostering student discussion and focuses on random details sometimes.

She's a hard professor but knows her stuff. She helped me become a better paper writer/English major. She is more than willing to help you. I had a hard time but still managed to get a B in the class. She's not as mean as she seems.

She's pretty tough, but for the first time in my college career, I felt like I actually learned something about writing literary essays. She's very enthusiastic and willing to help you out if you talk to her privately. Overall, she made a good impression on me. Unlike many professors, she really knows her stuff.

There were a few rotten apples with huge attitude problems in the class.  But Prof. Bernstein succeeded in making me interested in a topic that I was not excited about before. We were allowed 3 absences, which is plenty--if you don't want to go to class, drop out.

This woman is boring beyond belief. She took a very interesting topic and decided to bore us with petty details about characters/books (gag - Uncle Tom's Cabin - run for your life) along with tons of other slave narratives which have not only been done before, but are awfully boring. She requires mandatory attendance too: all any of us wants is out

She's a very caring and engaging professor. She chose wonderful texts for the syllabus, also pretty easy as long as you pay attention. She could be a little better at encouraging discussion, and it helps to have some background in lit theory, although it isn't necessary.

Bernstein is a great and enthusiastic teacher.  She's really interested in gender issues in Victorian novels and it shows in her class.  She uses powerpoint presentations effectively and makes the class interesting.  This was one of the first English classes I took, and it made me want to major in English!  I highly recommend her!

Sometimes her lectures are hard to follow...she's big on using large words, when concise explanations would do.  She made me feel stupid when I asked her a question about my thesis instead of helping me.  Semi-interesting stuff.
A lot of times her lectures are quite hard to follow, but if you can catch on to what she is trying to say she has some pretty impressive insights.
She has the uncanny talent of taking five minutes of material and turning it into a 50 minute lecture.
